We urge stakeholders to submit public comments on the proposed amendments to ensure the custody rule for investment advisers is modernized appropriately.

At the very least, the SEC should demonstrate the extent to which digital assets are linked to registered investment advisers' clients before considering this proposal, as it appears intended to compel advisers to sever connections with the digital asset ecosystem.

The proposed amendments to expand the current custody rule to include all client assets‚Äîincluding all digital assets‚Äîshould be debated and decided by Congress, not an expansive reading of the authorities granted in Dodd-Frank beyond Congressional intent.

Chair Gensler's approach, paired with Staff Accounting Bulletin 121 and other recent regulatory actions, only seek to chill digital asset markets.
 
This is not the right approach and leaves us with more questions than solutions.

Republicans believe safeguarding customer assets is critical. 
 
Customer assets must be properly segregated and protected from being lost, misused, stolen, or misappropriated, as well as in the event of insolvency or bankruptcy.

Our office is working with federal authorities to determine what changes are needed to prevent such disasters from occurring in the future, and key to these changes will be the results of the ongoing federal investigations.
#NorfolkSouthern must withhold no expense in remediating the human and environmental toll this derailment and spill have created.
Greater Cincinnati Water Works has informed us that every measure is in place to ensure our water supply is protected against these and other contaminants stemming from the spill in #EastPalestine.
According to ORSANCO, their testing at the location closest to Southwest Ohio shows the presence of Butyl Acrylate at less than one part per billion ‚Äì well below the level of concern.

ORSANCO is rigorously testing for chemicals around the clock at 16 different locations along the Ohio River. Butyl Acrylate ‚Äì one of the main chemicals being tested for ‚Äì is considered to reach a level of concern at 560 parts per billion in water.

Our office is in touch with the White House, Governor Mike DeWine, Congressman Bill Johnson, U.S. EPA, Ohio EPA, Ohio River Valley Water Sanitation Commission (ORSANCO), Greater Cincinnati Water Works, and other local, state, and federal authorities.
Folks are understandably concerned, but here‚Äôs what we‚Äôve been told: Southwest Ohio‚Äôs water is safe to drink.

I was thoroughly impressed with the thoughtfulness, compassion and humanity that they managed to display in the darkest of moments.
The common thread that tied these visits together is that our law enforcement and first responders often run toward danger without having time to process the risk to their own lives.

I ended the day with a visit to our 911 dispatchers, who did heroic work Monday night as chaotic calls were coming in from across campus and Lansing, including the tip that ultimately tracked down the suspect.

Next, I met with our Meridian Township and Lansing Township Police and Fire Departments, who were among the first to clear the building and the Union. Some found students hiding hours later in the upper floors of the building, while others transported the wounded to Sparrow.
So many students were unable or unwilling to set foot in the building again.

I couldn‚Äôt help but wish every elected official could visit the site & feel a part of what our kids & professors felt in those terrifying hours. What took my breath away was how many personal articles, especially phones, that were still left to be picked up.
On our tour, we walked past room after room whose doors had been breached by law enforcement looking for students barricaded inside.
The care with which they helped students through this painful process came from being parents themselves.

I started today at Berkey Hall, one of the two sites of the shooting, & got a tour from our local FBI. The agents, victim advocates, & therapy animals were on site as students & families returned to recover the personal belongings they left behind as they ran for their lives.
Today was a day to thank our first responders ‚Äî and to gain a deeper understanding of the traumatic impact Monday's tragedy had on our MSU students and our community.
